Instead of focusing on events or characters, the scenario likes to stray into emotional blackmailing, with some scenes awkwardly turning to be overly dramatic, adding unnecessary emphasis on the good reasons and innocence of the Israeli people and stretching the dialog to depict and justify their "good intentions" in borderline ridiculous ways. That and the little speeches full of political messages.. really not sure all those not-so-subtle arguments add anything to the movie, just load it with biased views and unpalatable justifications. Hollywood may like it, but Spielberg soils himself by engaging in such partisan projects.

title: Surprisingly inept and trite
review:
In this depiction of the Spring of Youth and Wrath of God operations following the Munich "massacre", we're expected to believe that, with a heavy heart, the Israelis decide to exact revenge on those responsible. I'll avoid the topic of historical and ethical clumsiness in this film because opinions on them abound and this review would become a book.

When Zwaiter fell forward onto his groceries he then magically flipped onto his back for the next view. Judging by the weapons, he was shot with at least .380 cal rounds yet a smaller (.22 centrefire?) calibre cartridge case was picked up. With 10 torso shots (though a grocery bag containing glass vessels of liquid: deflection/retardation) and none to the head, many people could survive.

The film continued it's ineptitude so remorselessly that I only watched to get the thing out of the way. The characters are thin, foolish and laughable, particularly Steve (Daniel Craig) dancing and suggesting they go to Libya to extend their mission. In the scene with Louis (Mathieu Amalric) and Avner (Eric Bana), sensitive topics are discussed in a public place using plain rather than implied language.

If this were just an action-thriller the theatrics and ineptitude would be fine but it's supposed to be a serious topic about an abhorrent government policy and that makes a mockery of its overall intent. Whatever it may be. The point is well enough made but I had little sympathy for Avner by the close of the film. The cast do a passable job, Geoffrey Rush is his usual professional self but Daniel Craig needed to talk to a South African for longer to get his accent right.

title: The same old story
review: You can watch that one without getting bored and another point is; all the hairs, cars, outfits are so cool and reflecting the 70s way(except dutch girl!! Becus i couldn't feel if she was from 70s or 90s). Eric Bana and Louis(i forgot the real name) acting cool, too. However, i've seen tones of movies from Spielberg that told us the exposed-Gewish people or Gewish massacre...I wonder when he will stop making the same story. Meanwhile, there was thousands of massacres in the history and some of the have been still going on somewhere in the world. That kind of brandmark director should rise his head up and see the others, as well. If he thinks he has right to protest China about human rights, then he must have responsibility to have a look at the different nations' pains. I don't like the end of movie. It was like Kushner&Roth couldn't finish it what it really had to, although they also knew what the real end. I don't like the bed scene near the end, either. It was like to fill some space, so poor to reflect the Bana's emotion and highly ordinary to picture that kind emotional explosions.

title: Engaging drama except for a couple uber lame scenes
review:
Would've given it more points if someone had edited out the preposterous flashbacks to an event in Munich at which the main character was not present. I feel sorry for the relatives of the real Israeli athletes for the tacky association of their tragedy with some murder-for-hire guy humping his wife.

Also struggled with the scene of Louie's papa preparing a big family dinner at their country estate and chatting up the Israeli assassin. Having lived in France, I can say that the mere concept of a wealthy man preparing a big family meal is a joke. But the blindfolded guest and instant bonding are even more cornball.

title: best film ever.
review: i'm 15. and to be honest, i thought i'd never understand a complex and serious film, when my film collection ranges from the saw's to harry potter. i don't think enough people know about this issue to be quite honest, and as its taught me more, i can use it for my gcse's, i've never watched a more amazing and like cultural? film. i cant even describe how it makes me feel!i understand this film this film has fully opened up my eyes to problems beyond my own, i feel like its inspired me, this film is so powerful, i got it for Christmas, i have watched it like 20 times since then! and cried like every time. i recommend it to everyone. its full on amazing! anyone got any recommendations of similar films? x

title: A film only Steven Spielberg could do
review: This one of the few good movies that came out during 2004 and is one of the best in last 5 years. Steven Spielberg is considered one of the best film makers of all time and this film certainly proves that he is. Spielberg is not the only one that shines also the actors play a major part in this film masterpiece. Eric Bana dose a absolutely superb job and also does Daniel Craig both should at least got Oscar noms but didn't. Eric plays a very good father away from his baby and the soldier how wants to get home.The story isn't that fillmler with a lot of people but don't let you from stopping yourself from watching this movie. This certainly a film that should not be missed and hoping that it becomes a classic.

title: It's a remake!!!
review:
How many times do we have to remake a film before someone cries foul, and the Hollywood establishment has to start coming up with original ideas...

Spielberg's "Munich" offers some slightly different, more emotional viewpoints than the 1986 made for TV movie "Sword of Gideon"... And while historical TV footage is artfully inter-cut, to perhaps integrate the story to better effect. But, Munich is almost entirely, shot for shot, the same film...

Each scene is unabashedly laid out, almost exactly as "Sword of Gideon". Even details, like the scene where the assassins bullets go through the grocery bag and spill the milk is the same... It's as though Spielberg used "Sword of Gideon" as his personal storyboard...

I am very tired of seeing remakes of films which have already been done well... How many times do we have to see the same movie under the guise of a different name? And why do we have to see a talented director like Spielberg express the same idea virtually the same way, all the while pretending that the execution was his original expression?

While updating a film , maybe once, to bring it to a new and wider audience, may be acceptable... At least do it with some originality... Cookie cutters are for making cookies, not movies...

Hollywood seems to be on a bandwagon of churning out remake after remake. As well as every comic book or "graphic novel" that has ever existed...

Is this what a majority of movies have been reduced to? Retreads, comic books, and franchise serial films???

My sensibilities are being assaulted and underestimated by studios, directors and producers who have decided that this level of pablum is all that the modern moviegoer can digest... No wonder box office sales have been limp of late...

Aren't there any more original ideas to be expressed? Have directors and writers just stopped reading books? There are a wealth of great stories out there...

Someone in should invent a new job for a production assistant in movie-making. Someone whose job it is to read books and to bring the new stories to the attention of the overburdened film industry...

title: true story
review: at first when i looked at the box and seen 2:44 run time i was like oh no,, i'll be bored, but to my delight i was not. the only thing that i wish that they would have done in this movie is shown more of the planning involved in the actual killing of the hostages at the Olympic area, other than that i liked the movie in general with few complaints. the object was to kill those responsible for munich , 11 of them i believe, there is also a mention of Carlos the Jackal midway through the movie. i thought it was funny that the team leader of the assassain group was a chef, you had the bomb maker,, the identity fixer, and the guy who cleans up other people's messes. on the whole the movie seemed to be very accurate in fact, based on a book written in 1984. there is lo'ts of blood and gore in this one, some action, but not as much as i would have liked, from a historical point of view i think it was a good movie, just bugged me where they started the movie,, they s hould have started say like the day before, but enjoyable throughout, with only one or two parts that should have stayed on the cutting room floor.

title: Well made but overlong
review:
This was a movie that I really didn't know what to expect.I knew the basic story and also knew that it was based on fact,but I hadn't felt the need to watch it as the trailers had left me cold.Was it worth seeing in the end?Yes,it probably was.But it isn't one of those films that I could watch over and over again.

The things that I liked about this film was the level of tension that was built up before each 'revenge' mission.They are all dealt with very well and are also well staged.The acting is also fine with no dud performances.

What I wasn't too keen on was the length of the movie.As with many films today it was too long and could have been at least 20 minutes shorter.The main problem I had was the way the revenge gang suddenly developed a conscience towards the end.This felt forced and unconvincing and only Daniel Craig's character Steve showed very little remorse throughout.From being a clinical bunch of professional killers,too many of them changed their political viewpoint.

So 'Munich' is a well made movie but no classic.Worth a watch but a slight disappointment.

title: Disappointing
review:
Another disappointing film from Spielberg! In the first place, this doesn't look like a $75 million production. The cast looks authentic, but the actors are not allowed to show what they are capable of.

Compare this film with 'Paradise Now' made by an Israeli Palestinian, and showing the journey of two Palestinian suicide bombers. You can be sure that their budget was minuscule.

It's okay to take a documentary approach; non-judgmental and neutral. However, the filmmaker has to have an incisive POV. What's the point of this endeavor?

Spielberg is trying to say that violence brutalizes the participants, and does not lead to peace. Pretty trite, unless you can deliver the emotional punch of Paradise Now.

The documentary footage and reenactment of the Munich fiasco does have an emotional impact for those who lived through those days. But, what value does this film add for them? What's in it for the rest of us?

How could Spielberg have provided a documentary perspective?

It is rational to deter an enemy by the threat of retaliation. Eleven Palestinian operatives for eleven Israeli victims.

The lamentable point of the Israeli-Palestinian struggle is that retaliation does not work for Israel because of their political objectives.

That is, the expulsion of non-Jews from Israel and the occupation of occupied territories by Jewish settlers. That is why the actions of this group of Israeli operatives were futile.

On a historical note, Israel ceased its operation after the wrong man was killed in Norway. Five Israeli operatives were caught and convicted.

The Palestinians ceased their operations in Europe after they realized that the attacks were a political liability.

title: Almost Complete Remake!
review:
This film is a typical victim of the modern hype Hollywood uses. While professionally shot, well-acted, and all the rest, it is at end merely a remake of an earlier flick on the same subject! The first movie, starring Michael York and others, is a little brighter than this one, but for all Spielberg's vaunted talent, the latter is more or less an episode-by-episode remake of the first.

No real insights, new vision, etc. I found the remake disappointing as a consequence, and more than a little pretentious.

What further bothers is the shamelessness of the plagiarism. He could just as well imitated Rossini when pressed to compose an opera in a short period: take an old one--the Michael York version, in this case, and appended a wimpy there-is-no-right-or-wrong message at the end.

title: What a let down.
review:
This is a film about a fascinating subject; it may not be true but fascinating all the same. A bit like 'The Day of the Jackal'  nothing to disprove it ever happened.

I remember watching the Olympic Games in 1972 on the television; these were my Olympic Games; I had the time to watch all the events, I had a great new colour television set and I knew a lot about the track and field events. This was the time of David Bedford the great British middle distance runner; he was breaking records for the 5000 and 10000 metres almost every week and he was set to show it to the world in the Olympic Games in Munich in 1972.

We turned the television set on one day and all hell had broken loose; we didn't understand what was going on; we couldn't understand why anybody could find something more important than the Olympic Games; why couldn't they, at least, let us see the 5000 metres final or even the 1500 metres? But it was serious; every time we watched the TV there was a hooded man standing on a balcony; the camera was fixed off and commentators all around the world spoke to their respective countries and filled time as we watched the fixed off shot.

We thought that the Olympic Games would be abandoned but it was not to be; one morning we got up and we were told it was all over; the entire Israeli team had been killed at the airport; it was reported that the Germans had opened fire on the helicopter, taking the hostages and terrorists to some destination or other, and that all on board the chopper had been killed.

They decided to cancel the Olympic Games for one day in respect for those killed and then they resumed; David Bedford, the greatest middle distance runner in Britain didn't win anything; the 5000 and 10000 metres were both won by a Finnish runner who, it was alleged doped his own blood.

So this film is supposed to fill in the blank spaces for us, the people who were transfixed to our television sets all those years ago; I'm not sure whether it does that or not or whether it just gives us the interpretation of a Mister Steven Spielberg.

It tells of the Israeli cabinet meeting deciding to send a crack assassination squad to kill the master minds behind the Munich massacre. "We have 11 Palestinian names; each one of them had a hand in planning Munich. We want them all dead." This could have been a riveting thriller but it isn't; it was directed by, arguably, the most successful director in movie history, written by maybe the most successful playwright living, Tony Kushner, and Eric Roth a successful screenwriter.

So what went wrong because this isn't a great film; maybe they should have contacted people from the other side? The film starts off okay but then goes into soap opera and propaganda; just look at some of the lines from the movie: "The only blood I care about is Jewish blood." "We kill for our future." "We kill for peace." These lines make you ask yourself what this film would have been like if made by Martin Scorsese; as it is it tries to be too many things.

It tries to be funny; for example; the bomb maker  and I'm not giving anything away and spoiling anything, doesn't make the device big enough for one killing and makes it too big for another killing  this is shot for comedy and nothing should be funny about it; one victim is shot as he carries a bag full of groceries  now why did they do that? So that he could be shot through the shopping bag and that the bag could leak of milk  you know the scene we have been watching it for years but this was shot by one of the most successful directors in the history of movies  just not good enough.

At one point the assassination squad are given a 'safe house' in Athens only to find that they are sharing it with other terrorists; there's a bizarre scene as if they are at a boy-scout jamboree and shouting out their troop names; IRA, ETTA, Bader-Meinhof; then they settle down and all sleep in the one room; this gives us an excuse for the two leaders to talk and philosophise about their beliefs with the leader, Avner, not letting on he is Jewish, of course, but the scene is a clumsy effort to educate and preach to us  the audience and we know how the relationship is going to end.

The film is also very annoying in its use of the zoom lens; I thought zooming had gone out of fashion since the seventies but no; it's just lazy and saves them using tracks and cranes.

There are some nice performances from Ciarán Hinds and Geoffrey Rush but what a let down.

title: This may contain spoilers
review:
It was a very good picture but my comment is, "What did the sex scene, having sex with a pregnant women have to do with the picture. Is nothing sacred today. I am tired of seeing scenes in the toilets,and vivid sexual acts. Don't you producers and directors have any imagination. Stop shoving such pornography down our throats. Give us some decent movies to watch.I have watched many movies directed by Steven Spielberg and enjoyed everyone of them, so I knew that Munich was going to be a good movie, but was very disappointed to see the scene with the pregnant women having sex. It wasn't necessary and also not in good taste. Please clean up some of these scenes in the future.

Nancy Riley

title: A good movie but not a great movie
review:
The most important thing about this movie is its central message, that revenge is a circle. It is also particularly important to focus this message on middle east conflict, because as everyone knows, the rest of the world is constantly drawn into this cycle of violence. I think Spielberg has done a noble thing in going after this issue.

Also important is the criticism Spielberg makes of governments. I believe that a government should never compromise its ethics, no matter what the cause. Sadly, reality has shown us that our governments can be just as evil as the terrorists. If we become our enemy to fight them then what are we fighting for? When this happens there are no good guys, and the conflict becomes pointless.

However, the implementation of this film leaves something to be desired. I believe the violence and gore was excessive. In fact, the scene with the woman having blood squirting in a nice clean stream out of her chest was really not necessary.

Some might argue that this was realism. Of course, it might have also been realistic to have her fall backwards onto a jagged board and have her beating heart speared like an olive and spraying the whole room. Maybe we could have seen her hungry cat snacking on her liver several days later. No one could say that it probably wouldn't happen.

It appears that those in Hollywood have decided that an affective way to stimulate movie goers is to show them shocking violence. Of course, they are right, it does stimulate the mind in a primitive way. However, it is also an easy, lazy minded way to stimulate us. Much easier than actually telling a good story, making us think, or inviting us to a different reality for a couple of hours.

My other criticism of this movie, is that it moved from assassination to assassination quite linearly, and monotonously. It was like watching a long train go by and trying to read the writing on every car. After about the third one, I was loosing interest. A couple of shots of newspaper front pages for some of the killings would have been more efficient, and would have saved them a ton of money, and made the movie better.

Overall, the acting was pretty good.

title: The athletes were shot, the movie is too
review:
After the blockbuster "War of the Worlds", Steven Spielberg quickly followed it with a very different of movie: an historical drama about the killing of the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich by Palestinian terrorists.

The situation of 2005 was often compared to 1993. That year, Spielberg made the most-successful film of history (at the time): "Jurassic Park". It was quickly followed by what was about to become Spielberg's undisputed masterpiece: "Schindler's List", which won seven Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Director.

While "War of the Worlds" is a terrifying and spectacular sci-fi action thriller, "Munich" is a very ambitious project, but it ultimately fails to satisfy our expectations.

Let's examine the film point by point. The beginning scenes with the Palestinian terrorists and the Israeli athletes start the movie pretty well. We feel the interaction between the terrorists and the hostages. The mêlée with the terrorists and the police at the airport is thrilling. Unfortunately, it's very uncomfortable to edit it as a Avner's (Eric Bana's character) flashback. It would have been even more convincing and real if it was told in a linear sequence at the beginning of the movie. However, it could have meant that Spielberg would have had to chop out the TV footage, which are quite fascinating.

It tries to be a thoughtful drama about Israeli-Palestinian relations, but it never involves us in an interesting way. It depicts Israelian dialects and traditions, but that's all.

Characters try to be interesting and dramatic enough, but the most interesting are the gang members. Eric Bana is very touching and professional by moments, but he often acts too much spontaneously and we don't believe him. Steve (played by future-super-spy Daniel Craig) is cool and he acts quite well in mood-enhancer scenes, such as the moments where he and an Arab companion argue about the station they will put on the radio.

The plot is too much complicated and the only thing we know for sure is that they have to shoot eleven Arabs who are supposed to be related to the Munich events. We quickly lose ourselves in the action and dialog doesn't help. I never knew the name of some important characters before I saw the credits.

Because it was so much discussed, publicized and aimed by high expectations, "Munich" is the kind of work that brings Spielberg back to Earth. It's not because you have a good concept, a good name and a good streak that you're gonna have a good movie. There are fairly good moments in the film, but it's not what it could have been. "Munich" is good, but it's also disappointing.

title: Good on style, highly selective on accuracy.
review:
Did the film makers actually bother to do any research or just make this up as they went along? I suggest anyone interested in the real story behind the assassination teams dispatched around the world relating to these events dramatised in the film seek out documentaries on the subject and study the recent material now in the public domain.

I find the most risible aspect of this picture was the choice not to mention the botched assassination of a Morrocan waiter working in Scandinavia wrongly identified which brought the whole state sponsored campaign of selective targets to light and should act a warning that no matter how sophisticated your intelligence is, there is always the inevitable errors that lead to innocent casualties.

title: Spielberg misses the mark
review:
I went into this film expecting another Schindler's List masterpiece. Despite the hype, what I ended up viewing was an overwrought, predictable, and plodding work of mediocrity.

First of all, Munich tries too hard to be "artsy" in its pacing, cinematography, and dialogue. Though it tries to portray itself as a Greek-type morality and tragedy play (i.e., "are we becoming the same monsters we're killing?"), it largely fails.

SPOILERS ********************************** The story progression is predictable. I could easily foresee every "plot twist," such as the phone bomb scenario. We knew the little girl was going to somehow reenter the house. Likewise, Avner's tirade in the Jewish consulate was forced and predictable.

Spielberg has, of course, had many great successes. Despite the poignant subject matter, this film was 2.75 hours of my life that I wish I could get back.

title: So this is your solution, Mr. Spielberg?
review: I felt a lot of things when the movie ended, convinced was not one of them. Munich follows the exploits of an assembled team of hit men assigned by the Prime Minister of Israel lead by Avner(Eric Bana) to take out the plotters of the terrible Munich terrorist homicide. Spielberg claims this movie was a tribute to the deceased athletes, but after I saw the movie I couldn't tell if he was honoring them or spitting on their graves. The story immediately starts with the Palestine terrorist group posing as athletes making their strike(by the way,don't be shocked by the little US-backs-up-the-talibans node, you'll see later in the film why they did this and but be shocked by the fact that in the movie we never learn why Black September did his). After the hostage situation(though we don't see exactly how it ends), we are treated with a briefing room where the Isreali PM Golda Mier(Lynn Cohen) and his military intelligence plan the counter-strike,enter former PM bodyguard and Mossad agent Avner, who is selected for this job as they travel to various locations in both Germany and France, while Headquarters wires them money every now and then(Don't ask me why do they paid them in US dollars and why should they keep all the receipts), they spend most of the movie taking out all of their targets and occasionally buying inside information from «people who refuse to work for governments», that is until they realize someone else is also stalking them(we never know who they are and what's the CIA's part in all of this?) and Avner starts getting paranoid and questioning his assignment(and also having visions of the massacre he did not witness,odd to say the least), especially when some his teammates are killed one by one. For the most part, it's entertaining(but hardly Oscar material) even if a little long, there's a degree of graphic violence that can be quite shocking. The musical score is decent, however the storyline and the message it conveys is what turns people off. In case you didn't know, this was based on a book by George Jonas, who's source was supposedly a former Mossad agent, this source had approached another writer but he passed on it, citing that the source kept changing details and most of the stuff he mentioned didn't click. George Jonas's work has been pretty much debunked ever since, but Spielberg in the wake of the post 9-11 world decided to pick it up, give some spin and adjust the context, just like an old nasty forum topic,to be brought back to life like a zombie only to pray on the uninformed and on the easily influenced and on top of that it lectures as by blurring the clear line between justice and revenge(in a very childish manner, mind you) The plot often is so unclear(no explanation for Avner moving his family to New York, no background on Louis, sudden unexplained changes in the characters,a bomb maker who only knows how to defuse them, absurd murder situations, a PM who claims going after killer was against their values) it really feels like it was based off a fiction novel then an actual account of these supposed events. Jews are portraying as willing murderers and Palestinians are portrayed as just terrorist(though the plotters look like harmless and sociable types, gee, just like the Israeli athletes). In the end, Steven what you're saying is that your solution to something like 9/11 is: either a) pretend nothing happened and negotiate with terrorist(assuming of course, they won't do it again) or b) chase them down and in turn become the very thing they swore to destroy. So your solution is that self-defense is just as bad as being striked upon. And that World Trade Center shot basically says: The US hunting down Osama Bin Laden, his al-quaeda buddies and the countries who sponsor them is no different then Osama Bin Laden's disposable pawns killing hundreds of Americans, Spanish, British and others. Sadly, Steven, you fail to realize that unlike you, the President of The United States is responsible for the safety and freedom of his people and the free world and I doubt bringing Osama to justice is against their moral values. Make no mistake it's a decent thriller, but it's best not to take the facts the movie throws at you as gospel. But if you want a movie that explores the difference between justice and revenge in a more mature fashion without preaching go watch Batman Begins(Yes, seriously).

title: Comparison to Sword of Gideon
review:
I really find it hard to believe that all the hype concerning Munich fails to even mention a film entitled "Sword of Gideon" that was made some 20 years earlier. That film, starring Steven Bauer, Rod Steiger and Michael York raised the same moral issues as Munich but in a much more subtle way. I found Spielberg's "hit you over the head" commentary on the moral of the film condescending. I also believe the acting in "Sword of Gideon" was much better. The story line in "Sword of Gideon" was more logical and left the viewer with very few unanswered questions regarding its development.

I really think somebody (hopefully an honest critic) should compare the two movies so that others can learn of the existence of "Sword of Gideon and then decide for themselves which movie is better.

title: Bold and worth watching, but significant flaws keep it from masterpiece status---6/10
review: Munich takes a bold look at the MidEast conflict by examining the 1972 Munich massacre and it's aftermath. Steven Spielberg, widely revered in both Hollywood and the Jewish community, puts his neck out by (finally) criticizing Israel and it's politics, if just a little. Israel would make you think it's an anti-semitic film, but in actuality it is a fair look at the pros and cons of both political views. Eric Bana and Daniel Craig lead a Israeli assassin squad ordered to hunt down and kill all those responsible for the killing of 11 Israeli athletes. While the movie has some really exciting scenes and tries to be fair, it is way too long and sometimes seems lost, like it doesn't know which direction it wants to go next. Spielberg could have easily trimmed a half hour of fat off the film. There were some really good scenes in the movie, but they were few and far between. I commend Spielberg for taking risks and giving Palestinians a few moments in the movie to speak; i just wish he packed up all the good stuff in a tighter package. 6/10

title: Nothing special
review: Nothing Special. OK movie, started out strong. The film become too artish with the ending. I know the anxiety's were reflected, but I like the documentary feel of the beginning. Acting is perfect. The ending, what is with that? The dinner comment? I believe the actor wanted to escape his past at the ending. The commando part is good. A movie rental. Nothing special. OK film. I would not buy it. I wonder how real the film is? Not a date movie. Film in a dark tint, I wonder if such a back ground was for the mood of this film? No humor or release in the film. Comments about the policies and ideas of the people, in a political way.

title: "...I could go on and on ..."
review: With the splendid "21 Hours at Munich" in the back of my mind I sat down to watch Spielbergs doc-drama or perhaps fleshing out of the latter. The overshadowing question that gradually develops for me long before the first half of the movie has passed by is, where is this movie going or what is it about? Several clues might be found in the first assassination in the film of a write/translator who to an engaged audience praises the power of the narrative and equally throughout a recurring theme of a never ending replacement of 'targets/names'. The new target/name, we discover, far worse than the first and perhaps not so dissimilar to the dialog which struggles to reflect on events. As a snippet from the dialog at the end of the film sounds, '...I could go on and on ...'. And so it does only tempting the audience through change of exotic era-true cosmopolitan scenery and clockwork-carnage.

title: Spielberg goes out his comfort zone - was it worth it?
review:
As someone with limited sympathy for the politics of either Israel or Palestine, I went to see this film with no little degree of trepidation. As the film got under way, I felt I might be pleasantly surprised. It was a thriller, based on a historical incident, and well-told. With the demise of the Cold War, stories about secret service plots, espionage and counter-intelligence seem too few on the ground, and criticising a Spielberg film for being pro-Jewish seems as silly as criticising James Bond for being pro-British.

The film takes the 1972 terrorist attack on Israeli athletes at the Olympic games in Munich as its starting point and then follows one of the hit squads assigned to revenge the attack (it is based on a book that straddles fiction and non-fiction lists called 'Vengeance').

As targets are identified - some of them a bit too old to have been the young Munich assassins - they are wiped out with varying degrees of skill, lack of skill, or bungling. The assassinations generally inflict unintended civilian casualties, and the assassinated are quickly replaced - often by better and more numerous terrorists.

Avner, the leader of our hit-squad sent by Israel's intelligence service (Mossad), eventually starts to succumb to doubts about the legitimacy, effectiveness and morality of the operation, as well as general paranoia (some of which seems reasonable) about whether the mercenaries selling him information are also selling information about his own whereabouts to enemies, or whether Mossad will endanger him and his family if he chooses not to take further missions.

This is where it all goes badly astray. Spielberg excels as a storyteller, not as a philosopher. With the remarkable Schindler's List, he told a story of bravery, of the non-violent and successful resistance and escape from the Nazis. The heroes were clearly defined and worthy of universal admiration. With Munich, he forces us to consider the current Middle East situation, where neither side is universally considered blameless. Avner's musings about the wrongness of violence are unconvincing and impotent. Although the film includes a few shots of Palestinian hardship, it nevertheless came across to me as a confused apologia for Israeli over-retaliation - in a similar ilk to Oliver Stone's cancellation of US guilt in Vietnam in 'Born on the Fourth of July' ('it was bad but necessary / well-intended, so let's move on').

Spielberg said he wanted the athletes to be remembered - but the film hardly shows them - you would be hard pressed to remember their names or anything about them from watching Munich. The martyrdom process that both the terrorists and Israeli assassins engender however is dwelt on for over two hours. It has come in for criticism from the Israeli government and the author of the book on which it is based. Spielberg said he hoped the film would produce discussion - it probably has and will, but possibly not of a useful or constructive kind. This, however, is my very personal view. By raising questions it might conceivably arouse productive debate within the Jewish community. My low rating is because it left such a bad taste in my mouth.

title: masterpiece? puhlease!
review: What a stinker. After reading about Spielberg's displeasure with regards to his studios apparent favoritism of Brokeback Mountain over Munich I felt compelled to give it a go and what a mistake. Anyone looking to catch up on their sleep will be pleasantly surprised. This thing sucked. Political ideologies aside, it was just plain boring. The fact that Israel sanctioned the assassination of the Munich terrorists would itself seem to foster an interesting enough screenplay but Spielberg manages to take any excitement and/or intrigue and bog it down with tiresome dialogue, bad accents and contrived characters. I found myself looking at my watch repeatedly wishing this steamer would end. Spielberg, check your ego at the door next time and leave the directing to someone with a pulse.

title: updated remake
review:
Over the years, I have really enjoyed Steven Spielberg movies, but this one I can only give 3 stars. Most people will find this a really great film, however, for those of us who remember the original TV movie "Sword of Gideon" (1986, starring Steven Bauer["Scarface"], Michael York, Rod Steiger, and John Hirsch) you will be extremely disappointed. "Munich" follows "...Gideon" almost scene by scene. They are the same movie 85% through; absolutely no originality. This seems to be a growing trend i.e. "Brothers" and "The Sons of Katie Elder" etc.

In summation, save your money and rent "...Gideon". The only REAL difference is the amount of fake blood.

title: This movie is in one word "Poor"
review: I went to see this movie after watching the trailer and hearing about it a few weeks before its release. This was my kind of movie and i went to it with good hopes and an open mind. I am not the kind of person who gets political or hates Israel or the Arabs, i watch movies as movies. I must say that this movie could have been a lot better if many things were fixed. It felt all wrong to me. First of all this hit squad was sloppy and simply incompetent. Everything is sloppy and it makes this movie very unrealistic and it is difficult to buy the story from beginning to end. Avner is a poor leader, his source of intel is questionable, he is not a professional Mossad agent, the whole movie feels like he doesn't know what he is doing. He is supposed to be a highly trained agent, efficient and and a pro at what he does, his crew is underequipped and the bombmaker turns out to botch several jobs. This top secret hit squad is supposed to be so clandestine that not even Mossad can contact him, but since many of the missions are disasters, eventually Avner himself gets tracked down. The dialogue is confusing, and frankly there is too much of it. I feel the people who made this movie tried to do too much with it and ultimately made it confusing, unclear, and long and boring. What needs to be changed is this... Less talk, more killing, a more realistic hit squad, and some clarity on this source guy. Mossad should have been giving intel to Avner. There is so many things that feel wrong that it took away a lot from this movie. This movie was about revenge, ones conflict with himself about killing people who he doesn't even know did anything wrong, a government who sent a hit squad to kill arabs to scare the arab world, and make us think about whether all this killing will eventually end and there will be peace.

title: Munich: Spielberg's best film in years
review:
In my opinion, Munich is Steven Spielberg's best film since Saving Private Ryan. From the opening scene with a depiction of the Munich massacre to the very end in New York, I couldn't take my eyes off the screen. It was one of the few times that I could feel my pulse racing during a movie. Spielberg does a great job of building up the tension for each assassination attempt the Israeli team tries on the members of Black September. Each time it seems that something goes wrong so it leaves the audience guessing what will happen next. Munich moves like a thriller but also is a morality tale on violence and revenge. Every member of the team heavily risks their own lives to complete their mission. The greatest example of the toll the mission takes on the men is Eric Bana's character. He has to leave his wife and newborn daughter, almost gets killed by his fellow team member, and begins to question whether the people they are after are really tied to Munich or not. By the end of the film, he becomes so paranoid that he hardly sleeps and is always watching his back.

Without a doubt Munich is Spielberg's most provocative film yet. Schindler's List was more of a tale about one man's change of heart and Saving Private Ryan asked the question of how much is one person's life worth. But Munich asks what is the price for killing someone. It seems to show that there is a heavy price and no reward. The men they kill are replaced by worse people and each of the members of the team become physically and emotionally destroyed in the process.

Munich is not Spielberg's best film, that belongs to Schindler's List. But in my opinion it could come an easy second with Saving Private Ryan. Bana gives his best performance yet and should at least be nominated for Best Actor, if not win it. Spielberg should get his third Best Director Oscar as he proves once again that he can tackle any subject no matter how controversial. Although I have not yet seen all of the movies that have gotten Oscar attention I think that Munich is the best film of 2005. If you have not seen Munich yet, I suggest that you do and get the rare experience of seeing a movie that not only thrills you but also makes you think.

title: I don't want to see it again but I think it's a masterpiece
review: I would like to disagree with comments that I've just read from pfarmer891 about Spielbergs Munich. I think that the main message was totally overlooked and your comments were mostly concentrated on facts that sometimes are useless. So what if the Fiction movie is not totally based on facts, but do you think you can actually get those facts straight in a conflict like this. If the movie ads on in order to created a clearer message, I believe it's not a crime. And I don't think that the message was the standard Hollywood "why can't we be friends". I thought it was the message of desperation and hopelessness about the situation in Middle East. And it makes the story even stronger when we look at out the same conflict in 2006 and realize that nothing has changed, because the violence has continued. If Spielberg would have taken sides, then that would've been a standard for the modern Hollywood - Israel is the victim and Muslims are all terrorists. I thought it was a very brave move by Spielberg to try to analyze the conflict from words of both Israelis and Palestinians. The "safe house" part of the movie might have seem ridiculous to you, but why, is it impossible now for people of those to nations to sleep under one roof? If you believe that, then the conflict is inevitable in your world. I think people who go to see this movie, should not come there trying to dissect every setting and decide if it can be fact or not, but look more deeply into the meaning of the film. Try to get rid of all the previous conceptions and just watch it from both sides and then see if you can decide who is right. I think that's the point, that it's no one. Too many people have died to naively believe that any of the allegations of the truth, be it from Israelians or Palestinians, can be justified.

title: Sadly Inevitable
review:
Mr. Spielberg has now sadly been drawn into this phenomenon we call terrorism. No civilized person will be allowed to be neutral on this subject in the coming years. Paving the way, as always, is the art world... heralding the coming of the subject of terrorism and the Middle East in particular as they invade popular culture and the debate begins to be democratized as it seeps out into the masses.

Before Cinema, Governments, Zealots and Radicals made their own rules, playing the power game of nationalism and politics free from the scrutiny of those they govern. Now, we are learning how deep the hatreds run among the players and how ruefully unprepared our elected officials are in combating it. Dramatized though it is in parts, Munich lets us peek at the sick momentum that builds within and without world events and the inevitable cause and effect that will ultimately, it seems, decide which group or cause will one day triumph.

I am saddened that Mr. Spielberg, who I'm sure, like all of us, would rather live in a world where there are no ugly realities to inspire such films as this, would feel compelled to tell the story of the Sword of Gideon. I long for the days when we could watch the summer blockbuster escapism, blissfully unaware that outside the theater was a desperate world fighting to remain civilized. The French arms-dealers who traffic in information and lives are such a great illustration of that time, swathed in their cultured hermitage, able to ignore the collateral costs of their family business with at least as much passion as they reserve for their cheeses and wine.

The Spielberg of the multiplex cinema generation has moved into darker, more uncomfortable waters, the only guide for the filmmaker and his audience is our own conscience. Here then is the echo of the mind that made E.T., Saving Private Ryan, Amistad and The Color Purple. He knows us so well, he's sure that inside we are as decent and civil as he is and he knows he merely has to show us the images and we will choose the right path. But they must be images we have not already been desensitized to, because the journey of Munich is not one we can observe from afar. In this journey we must be participants. Because we are of course active participants in the reality of Munich, in the debate about terrorism, in the prayer for a lasting peace, in the hope that men will someday care more about this world than they do the next world.

title: Spielberg does it again
review:
Wow. A great film. Spielberg does it again. The biggest controversies about the film are coming from political figures in the news and radio talk shows, not critics. Liberals are saying, "See! We should not be in Iraq." Conservatives are saying, "See! Hollywood's getting involved where they shouldn't."

Great actors. Great acting. I loved watching the characters struggle with their duties, but still performing them and then dealing with the emotions afterwards. War. The humanity felt in the consequences of war were shown so well in this movie. Excellent.

I would love to know how Spielberg was able to make this film without anybody mentioning that even though it is good it is also a remake. The book that it is based on, Vengeance, was already put to film in Sword of Gideon (1986). While Spielberg is getting the credit of a great film, which it is and he is entitled to, how can he be credited for something groundbreaking. It is a remake, and almost to the scene. I give him credit though. The movie definitely comes closer to the reality of world events, and therefor more emotional.

Great job. But, lets watch out on giving to much credit.

title: Monumental
review:
Very simply, truth is stranger than fiction. I feel this picture was superlative, it was real, and that's the way it was.

Three cheers for the Israelie's. Never Again!!!!!!!!!

I do not what more to say, the story was real, the acting superb,all the characters depicted where excellent.

I would certainly go to see the picture again. It was wearing but it was worth it. I have never clearly understood what happened in Munich the portrayal was entirely visible.

I went with my wife and it was tough but, real movie for her absorb. My son a daughter will be my next guest to see it.

Stephen Spielberg AND COMPANY. did a wonderful piece of work, and should be given many accolades for it.

Many thanks, I think I have covered all base and it was just great.

title: Excellent but no masterpiece
review: "Munich" is an very good movie but not Spielberg's best. I was alive at the time of the 1972 Olympics and watched the whole drama unfold on T.V. For many Americans, it was the first time we'd ever seen the ugly face of terrorism. This movie is that always dangerous combination, a docudrama, a film 'based upon real events.' In using George Jonas' 1984 book "Vengeance," Spielberg makes a critical error, for the book was widely criticized as inaccurate by knowledgeable sources, including former Mossad chief Zvi Zamir. The film is up to the usual high standard of Spielberg's past work - the film is intensely interesting and has excellent production values. However, it succumbs to some idiotic B-movie staples of past Holly wood fare, such as have two opposing groups - one Israeli and one Palestinian - share the same safe house, in which they meet with guns drawn but later become pals and house mates. Ridiculous. I enjoyed the movie but Spielberg takes a surprisingly soft view on terrorism, considering that he is a Jew. The PLO and the Mossad agents come across as morally equivalent, a view I do not share. Spielberg descends - for at least part of the movie - into standard Hollywood "Why can't we all be friends" bathos. Pretty simplistic and not very good history either. This movie is a fine example of why it is dangerous to rely upon Hollywood and movies for an accurate view of history. "Munich" is fictional, but uninformed viewers may take it as fact, which is a disservice to those who died. If you want a better view of terrorism, rent "The Battle of Algiers," a fictional movie but one universally praised for its accuracy. In fact, so accurate is "Battle" that would-be terrorists and also counter-terrorists screen the film. Of course, Spielberg's film is the better entertainment of the two, so pick on that basis. I give the film an 80 out of 100, or a 'B' grade. Nice effort but flawed. I wish he'd been willing to take a stronger stand morally. Whatever acts have been committed by both sides since then, Israelis were the victims at Munich, not the PLO.

title: Violent yet powerful story of the men who tracked and assassinated those perpetrating the 1972 kidnap and murder of Israele athletes at the Munich Olympics
review: Riveting and powerful, with strong performance; Eric Bana especially good. Best movie this year. Touching love story as subplot. Much violence, lots of spurting blood; beautifully filmed with good shots of Paris but many dark rainy nights on the streets -- a little too James Bond some times. Ciaran Hinds also very good but fake international German Hebrew accents at times detracted from the generally good dialog. Fabulous score by John Williams; great work by Spielberg with the overall theme that violence just begets more violence. Super character development of Avner, the lead played by Bana. At the end, the viewer is inside his poor paranoid head. Don't miss this one.

title: Spielberg Redeems Himself for the Last Three Years
review:
With Academy Award winning director Steven Spielberg's new film, "Munich," he redeems himself for the past three years which have turned out disappointing films from him (Catch Me If You Can, The Terminal, War of the Worlds, even AI) by going back to his Jewish roots and making a film whose topic affects his beliefs (as he did for "Schindler's List"). He also tackles a genre he has rarely tackled before in his career: a thriller The events at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, Germany are shown in four different parts throughout the film: Raid, Capture, Transport, and Tragedy. The film opens up with Spielberg's depiction of raid of the Israeli athlete's complex where Arab terrorist storm the building. With flawless editing by Michael Kahn, archive footage from 1972 is incorporated into the preceding event. However, even though the capture, transport, and tragedy aspects of Spielberg's depiction of the events is yet to be seen, it is the archive footage that tells what is happening and which provides the basis for the film's plot.

When the Israeli officials (including Golda Mier) decide to seek vengeance on those who killed the Israeli athletes at the Olympics, they propose to Avner (Eric Bana) to assassinate those who planned the Munich tragedy, with a team of other people played by Daniel Craig (aka the next 007), Mathieu Kassovitz, Hans Zischler, and Ciaran Hinds (in a performance worthy of an Oscar nomination).

However, while hired to assassinate, the team comes upon a number of obstacles from almost killing the pre-teen daughter of a target, to finding the targets by means of a headstrong Frenchman, killing an unplanned target, and the raging inner-demons of Avner's soul.

As Avner's soul progresses, he is haunted by the fact he can't see his wife and newborn daughter. Even when he hears his daughter say 'dada' on the phone, he breaks down completely and seeks for the woman he met in a bar. As his soul is ravaged by his inner-demons, he begins to come senile, even to the extent to sleeping a closet because he believes someone rigged in mattress with a bomb.

This film is the best of 2005, and Spielberg's movie of redemption for his aforementioned films. I can see Oscar nominations for Best Picture, Director, Editing, Supporting Actor (Ciaran Hinds), Score (John Williams), Writing (Adapted), and Sound Editing.

title: A movie that should be seen
review: This movie should be seen by all those who are of the proper age and not of the faint of heart. It was thought-provoking and horrifying, but did a very good job of addressing the question of, is an eye for an eye really the answer. I am a teacher and will suggest that my older students go nd see the film, so that we can discuss the moral issues brought up in it and also, what else could have been done by the Israelis, after the Munich bombings, instead of what was done, if anything. The film was very violent, however, I believe the violent scenes were done in an appropriate way, if there is such a thing, so that it was more painful than absolutely, gut-wrenchingly gory--don't get me wrong, there are some of those scenes too, but the focus was more on the plot than the blood and guts. I believe this is an important movie about an incident that far too many people know far too little about. This is the best movie I have seen in years.

title: Munchen ist phantastisch
review:
I have seen Steven Spielberg's new film 'Munich'.

I am largely an admirer of Spielberg's body of work. I think Schindler's List a chilling, singular film of a harrowing story, some sequences in Saving Private Ryan as close to actual combat as anything I've ever seen in film and Duel a model of efficiency in storytelling on an obvious budget. To a lesser degree, I enjoy his science-fiction/fantasy although this is not my favorite genre.

And now he's made a film which takes its story from the murder of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympics in Munich, Germany, by Palestinian 'terrorists'.

I use quotation marks here because the very term 'terrorist' has been so prostituted over the last forty years, made to serve obvious and, in some instances blatant, political agendas, it has become a largely useless term, it has become hard to know when it is being used truly to identify someone as a terrorist or even if terrorist is still a meaningful word at all.

I wondered here about Spielberg's choice to make this film and what exactly his 'story' would be. I trust Spielberg, I didn't want to be disappointed, but my antennae go up when a filmmaker decides to make a film, the very essence of which may turn on the pernicious usurpation of the term 'terrorist'.

Spielberg has been a gifted filmmaker from the beginning and, over the years, he has developed these gifts to a high degree. The film was visually and emotionally evocative, powerful will be a frequently used term. Nuance, however, has never been his hallmark, I wondered how deeply the contrasts would be drawn, how much black and how much white, how much gray.

Spielberg is a much greater filmmaker than I had imagined.

Oh, as drama, it has its faults. It seems overly long and some plot devices seem contrived, for instance, the general level of (in)competence displayed by the Israeli assassins should have been explored (it is not) and the family of French information brokers seemed implausible. But next to the remarkable achievement of successfully threading a moral needle which has eluded us all, these things grow pale indeed.

title: Munich is accurate to the bone of every Jew and Arab on the planet!
review:
Steven Spielberg broke out of his dry spell of horrible movies. "Munich" breaks through with numerous success and honors that achieve pride and joy, and much more it.

In a story that tells about the terrorist attacks on Israel and the retelling the hostage shooting (aka Black September), of the Israeli Olympic team. In retaliation, the Moussa (Israeli FBI) organizes a meeting to hunt down who was responsible for these wrongdoings, and kill them all.

Eric Bana (Avner), is the leader, and he's handed with 4 other man on a plot to kill, and a time for vengeance. In a span, they spend millions of dollars on weaponry and starting out on their spree to try and get them all.

Its a near graphic film, very disturbing, and it takes a lot in. However, its a terrific film, with lessons to learn and teachings to teach.

Who's the bad guy? Who's the good guy? That's all undetermined, but whichever it is, its your choice.

For generations ahead, this abides them all. This is a movie that should be presented for the future generations.

title: Movie tells both sides of story
review: This is an excellent movies that tells both sides of the story and is fair to all political factions involved. It is a mesmerizing movie, and thought provoking. It is far better the the drivel that has been coming out of Hollywood these days. Everyone with a social conscience and an interest in world peace should see this movie. Spielberg does not romanticize the events that have taken place or may have taken place. He gives us a hard look and a terrible period of our world's history. People may criticize the movie, but fair comment must come after viewing the movie and not reacting to hearsay and critics who have given the movie unfavorable press.

title: It's Spielberg - so it's Amazing!
review: I went in expecting what I walked out with. This was beautifully acted, wonderfully shot. The long movie held the audience and there was not one sound all through. It was like Schindler's List. A hushed reverence. Eric Bana is marvelous in a very difficult role. The lesser known actors were wonderful - including Daniel Craig who will soon be very well known as James Bond. This movie showed his acting skill rather than as a sexy secret agent as 007 is sure to do. No matter the controversy of "showing the other side" - the real heroes are the avengers, it just humanizes them instead showing them as robotic killing machines. The Black September group and the Palestinians are portrayed as they were/are. The Israelies are always obsessed with revenge because they must show the world they cannot be crushed. An eye for an eye - . Spielberg continues to remind the world "Never Again". I laud him for this. We urge him to continue making movies in this vein.

title: Superb...
review:
Should be a two disk set with Schindler's List...

No one is discussing the fact that this book was filmed before, for HBO in 86, as "Sword of Gideon"...

Same characters (more or less)...

Steven Bauer was especially good as Avner That was excellent, but this has much more depth...

The ending should strike home with a lot of people...

One of Spielberg's best...

Eric Bana is outstanding as is the rest of the cast...

Locals: A Editing: A Acting: A Length: Long but worth it...

Good to see a serious film that makes you THINK!

title: Spielberg tries something new
review:
In his political movies, Spielberg tends to polarize good from evil excessively to a point where some of the realism of characters and their feelings are lost.

Munich was a welcomed change. With all character glorification/dehumanization aside, Spielberg now takes us to a frame of time in 1972 which I haven't experienced since.. 1972.. The remarkable recreation throws you right into action and the emotional depth and inner moral conflicts that awashes these characters with genuine feelings that touch you and conflict you.

Most moviegoers will feel detached from the political message of the movie but it shouldn't discourage anyone to enjoy this true Spielberg thriller. Nudity and Violence abound... although in awkward ways.

title: Munich gets you where it hurts.
review:
Munich is one mess of a movie. Not because it is a bad movie. Matter of fact, it is an excellent movie. A movie that assumes you know the reality because it doesn't tell you where the reality ends and where the non-reality begins. In this case, you should know that Black September really happened, but it's the cause and affect that is being dealt to the public. It's the cause and affect this movie is really about. Whether the after-effect really happened, it doesn't matter. A mess was made and someone needs to clean it up. How do we fight fire? - with fire of course. How do you clean up a mess? - make a bigger mess.

That reminds me, this is a Spielberg movie that is nothing like the War of the Worlds he released earlier this year, but had the name not been used already, they could have called this one War of the Worlds, too. All the worlds - personal, political, familial, sociological, and any other you can think of - go off course and face possible annihilation. Gravity sucks you in and you can't escape. Maybe it was the black hole. No matter, you will become as engrossed in this movie. If you can forget about what you know politically or religiously, you will be ahead of the game. Forget about who is out to get who; watch what happens to those who let themselves get wrapped up in someone else's war.

Eric Bana's Avner becomes so wrapped up in death, life seems impossible to accept and yet becomes so dear. Daniel Craig will impress you as well. I think I see now why he was selected to be the new Bond. Cirian Hinds does a great job, also.

Why see this movie if you know about the true story? The story, the mystery and intrigue, Spielberg's best movie so far, great acting, self-realization...you name it. Just don't miss it.

I give it a 9/10 thanks to all the above reasons.

title: Incredible ride through Europe
review:
This had an excellent Bourne Identity feel about it -- something I did not expect to encounter.

The reviewers acted like this was a movie about Eric Bana's mental state, but it is in fact a very convincing account of how the Mossad probably functioned after Munich.

This was undoubtedly the best performance of Bana's brief career, and the movie's minor flaws are covered up by an incredible supporting cast.

The film borders on three hours in length, and the film features one tense moment for each of the 160 minutes.

title: Well Shot and Acted, Everything Else is Eh
review:
Steven Spielberg has made a lot of good historical dramas in his career. "Bridge of Spies" and "Saving Private Ryan" were both excellent, and "Schindler's List" is the best movie I've ever seen. I was looking forward to watching this movie, but unfortunately I was let down.

"Munich" follows a group of Israelis who are tasked with hunting down and killing the terrorists of Black September who were responsible for the Munich Massacre at the 1972 Olympic Games.

To make a historical drama good, you need one of two things. You either need an interesting historical figure to base the movie around, or you need an interesting historical event that's on-screen progression will enthrall people. "Bridge of Spies" and "Schindler's List" had both of these elements. "Munich" has neither.

The characters in the movie are all interchangeable with one another and have no real personality. The five members of Eric Bana's team are all the same person, except they each have a different skill.

The historical story chosen doesn't have anything of interest happening in it either. It is just a typical revenge story. Even more detrimental, it does not feel like there is a satisfactory conclusion to the story. It just isn't a very interesting piece of history to make into a three hour long movie. A better piece of history to focus on would have been the actual Munich massacre instead of the aftermath.

While this is a bad historical drama, I can not say in good conscious that is a bad movie. The movie is well written, well shot, well acted, and well directed for the most part. There is one scene where the way it was put together was confusing. The only technical aspect that was bad was the lighting, as every scene was saturated with light and looked ugly.

There are a lot of good historical dramas out there, and a lot of good ones made by Steven Spielberg. This is not one of them.

title: Munich The problem with losing friends
review: ***Spoiler Alert*** In the movie "Munich" it provides a theatrical look at the events that happened to the Israeli Olympic Team in 1972, along with detailing the events that happened afterward, or the untold story. The untold story about how Israel sent a hit squad to kill the eleven people who orchestrated the kidnapping and massacre of the team. The hit squad is led by someone who is not used to being the lead man of a group of people who are put together just to kill people, Avner Kaufman (Eric Bana). He finds it hard in the beginning to kill people but after killing a couple of people he begins to find it easier and easier to do so. This ends up being the moral dilemma for him that he is killing people and doing a good job at it. As him and his team are going on about extracting vengeance he learns that now he one of the people being hunted. And then begins to see his teammates being executed. The lighting in the film also transition with the attitude that Avner is feeling and the distress that he is feeling. During the beginning of film when he first sets out to conduct his hit job the lighting is somewhat light but then as his team continues to kill and they are ones being hunted the lighting changes to dark along with the mood and the feelings that the team has for the killings. This film could be compared to very loosely to "Windtalkers" directed by John Woo and starring Nicolas Cage where the ability to kill someone and losing your teammates becomes the theme of the movie.

title: what a joke !!!
review:
of course a joke .. when you present one sided view and close your eyes away from all the other points of view .. the work turned into a joke ... the movie cry about the violence and the assassination of athletes .. and close eyes away from all the massacre which done by Israel towards Arabs and Palestine ... what about sabra , shatila , kana . ghaza , kana again and areha all this mass murdering directed towards women . children and innocent and the number of victims exceed 12000 , but any of you or film makers know about it ... any of you or film makers has a gut to produce a movie present that massacre .. no of course .. as the money in USA is all jewes money and they control behind the curtains all politics and media .. abolishing the minds of Americans .. that awful assassination which is refused by me and by Islam ... is reaction to what Israel do in Arab not an action and also the dialogue has many mistakes like Arab hates Palestinian .. Palestinian are not Arab .. from what dirt you get that information ..

i am rating four .. for the spots of direction and the acting and some smart words about the truth of the conflict between Arabs and Israel ...also the end in which the hero refuse what the Israeli intelligence do and even refuse to come back to Israel

title: Enjoyed the movie, disagreed with the message.
review:
Spielberg has described "Munich" as his "prayer for peace," and that theme has overshadowed most of the real events this film is based on. It tries to see the actions of both sides, Israeli commandos and Palestinian terrorists, as equal. This brings down the film in an idealistic and preachy way.

When I first heard about this film, I was very excited that Spielberg would be directing it. I thought he could bring attention to the way Israelis have suffered under terrorism in the way he brought attention to the holocaust in "Schindler's List." Most of what I know about the Munich massacre and its aftermath comes from Aaron J. Klein 's "Striking Back," one of the most recent studies of the affair. What that work states is that the targets of "Munich" were high profile PLO members. The Israelis were anxious to fight offensively, not defensively, against Arab terrorists. Most of their targets did not have a direct hand in planning Munich. But in the film Eric Bana's "Avner" is not informed of this until the end, and it is presented to us as if the Israeli government is being shady, just eliminating people it had old rivalries with. The purpose of these assassinations was 1. to prevent terrorists from committing future attacks, 2.to deter terrorists by making them feel unsafe, wherever they were by knowing that while they sought the murder of Jews, they too could never sleep soundly at night, and 3. revenge.

"Munich" doesn't express well enough the motives for the reprisal killings, and the Israelis who take part in the operations are depicted as too somber and glum--Israel could not survive if its agents and leaders acted this way. Israeli prime minister Golda Meir, in the film, states the film's often quoted line, "Every civilization finds it necessary to negotiate compromises with its own values." In reality, Meir knew well that the perpetrators needed to be hunted down and punished, mercilessly. The impact of the targeted killings, especially the operation "Spring of Youth" in Lebanon, is not given proper significance in the film. "Munich" implies that each of these missions was a bloody, unnecessary mess that lead to more tit-for-tat violence. "Spring of Youth" made Israel's enemies look at the Mossad with tremendous fear and awe; that Israeli agents could hunt down and kill supreme heads of the PLO in an Arab country, while their targets lay in their own beds. The "deterrence" motive definitely seems to have been achieved by these operations. Although controversial, "targeted killings" have proved to be very effective. Israel brings the threat of death to those who plan terrorist attacks, and as a result, the terrorists spend 90% of their time hiding and only 10% of their time planning attacks. Avner says in the film, "Those we killed are being replaced by worse." This is a myth held by the world. True, everyone is replaceable, but often when a highly experienced, skilled, and charismatic Arab terrorist is killed, his replacement is a young person who can't understand the intructions of his weapons because they are in Farsi. Targeted kills are a blow to their organizations, and it is particularly demoralizing to terrorists when their "best" leaders are elminated.

My other complaint about "Munich" is that it feels rushed. Spielberg needed to slow down here, and he should have story-boarded the film. The Munich massacre is sped through too quickly, and there should have been more about how the Germans, with no anti-terror squad at the time, maddeningly bungled the rescue mission of the athletes. What Spielberg instead focused on was the violence (this is one of his bloodiest and most gruesome films to date). The final sequences, involving a concoction of scenes of Abner having rough, sweaty sex with his wife and the murder of the athletes, is bizarre and does not sit well. Many might find it offensive.

What do I like about the film? Well, at least Spielberg tried to make a personal film about the conflict. You can tell that his heart goes out to both sides in an idealistic way. The cinematography, lighting, set pieces, vehicles and costume design appear authentic and dead-on. It has a suspenseful opening and tense moments throughout. It is skillfully cast and all the actors do very well--especially Eric Bana, Geoffrey Rush, Omar Metwally, and Daniel Craig, who needed more scenes. Craig is the toughest, most gung-ho character and has the more memorable lines in the film, like "Don't f**k with the Jews," and "The only blood I care about is Jewish blood." The movie gives us great exotic locales and interesting character faces, and a noir-ish feel with a look into a shadowy world of espionage. The film seems at times more about the toll taken on government agents who do hard and ugly things loyally for their governments than about Israel and the Palestinians.

What we have in the end is a film that wears its heart on its sleeve. It is Spielberg's "prayer for peace," with some loss in accuracy as a casualty. Grade: B.

title: As boring as Schindler's List and as unsexy as ET
review:
Okay, Munich was good, but kinda overrated. Okay, I mean, it was no Lost World(what is????????:)and definitely no Color Purple. I mean, it wasn't even blue!!!!!!!lol:)Okay, and what was up with Saving Private Ryan.... that movie wasn't even believable... But starying put aside, Munich was the same movie, purely stylewise, as Schindler's list. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't great. It definitely wasn't amazing. ANd not that sexy And definitely not Jurassic Park.

So, I have decided to compose a list of Spielbergs greatest films....

1) War of the Worlds Unfortunately, I can't remember any others, cause the rest suck!!!!!!!

title: Politically Correct...
review:
I have to disagree with most of the critics. This film is not a masterpiece, but nothing more than a propaganda manifesto of political correctness, currently very much "in vogue" in 'developped western societies'. I rarely mix politics and films, but considering the aim and message of this movie, I cannot help myself from doing so in this case. I will therefore refrain from commenting on the technical and artistic aspects of the film and concentrate on the essence, which is highly politicized (to avoid any misunderstandings, I would like to clarify I am not Jewish, nor do I have any affiliation whatsoever with Jews or Israel).

This is a typical case of a film praised by all only because it has been made by a great director, and it carries a message almost everybody nowadays wants to hear: hear no evil, see no evil... It is far too simple to sit and preach peace on earth for all from a quiet place and at a safe distance, totally out of contact with reality, the harshness of the real world. Unfortunately, the reality is very much different from the one seen by looking out of a window of a multi-million dollar Villa in Hollywood. Life is a brutal game of survival; always has been, always will be. No matter how much we would like to think that the world is now a better place, that humans have evolved to being a non-aggressive, peace-loving species, the truth is nothing has ever changed since the dawn of time. We are still the same power-thirsty animals, fighting for dominance and survival. Only the means and the form of that fight have changed. We are fooling ourselves if we think that after the end of the cold war, now the world will quietly settle down and cuddle into an eternal period of universal peace. How blindsided can one get? There are wars everywhere, massacres perpetrated daily...

Notwithstanding the end of the cold war, the Russians still like to think of themselves as a superpower, they still see themselves as the 'anti-western' power, they still fear us and hate us, nothing has changed. The Chinese, very much the same. Do we honestly think they are our friends? Or do we prefer to do so because it is good business? The 'Islamic nation' on the other hand, is a story to itself. Do we really think we can simply sit together with the fundamentalists and talk it over? 'Talk it over' with people whose major ambition is to blow themselves up in order to try to kill one of us? Do we really think that they will be content with any kind of agreement? It hurts to think that so many people can be so foolish to believe such nonsense nowadays. Have we already forgotten the scenes of jubilation on the 'arab street' after 9/11? Mark my words: they will not stop before either they destroy us, or we destroy them..., whether we like it or not!

Freedom and peace are not a given, they have always come at a price. If we want to continue being free and to live in peace, we will have to fight for it. Just wishing for it to happen is not good enough! That is an important lesson we must never forget and remember to teach our children. This is why I consider the message that the film bears not only to be bad, incorrect or unrealistic; I consider it dangerous.

title: Poor at every level
review:
Viwed as a moralistic sermon, this may well work for some people. On a different level and for those like me unwilling or unable to take sides in the Israeli/Palestinian question it also fails abysmally as a credible thriller. The set-pieces were confusing with nothing to tell us where in the world they were located (although I did recognise a London Transport bus) and some of them simply insulted our intelligence.

To name a few: One of the fleeing Israeli athletes returns to the dorm, picks up a handy kitchen knife and sticks it - not in a terrorist's gut - but, with no discernible effort, in his forehead, pinning him to the wall. Spielberg should have done his research and worked out that it would take Superman to pull this one off.

The Mossad hit team hole up for the night with a band of Palestinians in total ignorance of each other's nationalities or motives. Yeah, right. Good job the Jewish guys kept their pants on!

The Dutch hitwoman: Why didn't she hang around and take out Eric Bana, her original target, too? She might have got paid double and been able to move out her little houseboat.

More laughably, when they go after her they take zip guns designed to look like bicycle pumps. What was wrong with a good, old-fashioned Beretta? What is more, against a person touted as a renowned freelance killer, they don't even bother loading their bicycle pumps until they corner her in the bedroom.

One last thing: I admire most of SS's work but am I alone in thinking that he has never got round to working out how to end a movie without overdosing us on the corn?

Think about it: Saving Private Ryan (the sheer cliché of that salute to the grave; Schindler's List (ditto for the stones on the grave); Munich (total anti-climax, so to speak); Artificial Intelligence, Close Encounters, ET, need I say more?

title: Pure Fantasy
review:
I hope that people do not ascribe any accuracy to the screenplay. It is ridiculous to think that a group of assassins gather at the last moment before commencing operations and get to know one another. Furthermore, the lead was completely untrained which is probably the case since they missed many opportunities to kill their prey quickly & cleanly. The foul-up in retaining the services of a bomb maker who only knew how to dismantle bombs hardly rings true, even for the CIA!

Kushner & Spielberg bend over backwards to provide ideological balance to the warring sides. It is obvious that the true nature of professional assassins do not make for good movie material...apparently there is a need for heavy emotional conflict in order to tamper down the exactitude and clarity of purpose that is actually the makeup of the professional "agency" hit-man.

A good shoot'em up...a Western set in fashionable European locales.

title: The Answer to Violence is Surrender
review:
Munich is a fine piece of excellent acting, fine directing and first class "progressive" propaganda. It's worth seeing, just as long as you keep aware of what's going on.

Don't be fooled by the fact that the Director and Screenwriter are of Jewish background.
