review: WOW..This movie was so much more than what I was expecting. The movie shows the angst of each of the main characters as they question whether their loyalty to their country and religion is worth killing men with loving families. Though I will not discuss what I believe to be the film's underlying theme, their are poignant scenes which underscore the futility of violence. While I do not know Spielberg's politics, anyone who says this movie takes sides is simply wrong. Like "Requiem for a Dream", this is a movie I believe many people with experience in the subject ought to see. In my opinion, this movie is the year's Best Picture so far.

title: Spielberg's greatest work
review: This movie was a delightful surprise for me. It is my tentative vote for best picture of the year. It has all the elements of a great movie. There is a good amount of violence, a good amount of nudity, great dialog, great acting, great directing, interesting plot. The length was a little less than three hours, and I was never bored. Although at some moments this movie was visually disturbing (graphic violence) I walked out of the movie with a great taste in my mouth. Eric Banna captures the fear of being hunted by unknown enemies perfectly, and all of the rest of the roles are cast perfectly. Much of the movie was shot in Europe, and these scenes are beautiful and do a good job of capturing European daily life. I can't think of another time when I was more pleased by a Spielberg film.

title: Thought-provoking!
review: The time went fast, a good sign. Rarely does one sit through this long a film with little or no squirm. The squirming came from subject matter. Other reviews have insinuated or claimed an ambiguous telling. I did not experience that, beyond the single pro-Palestinian rationale offered by a PLO agent in the film. Neither was a positive light cast for the Israeli actions, but the over-all feeling I am left with, having just watched it two hours ago, is futility. Not the film, no. It is an important film, worthy of posing the question, that being "is vengeance worth it?" Therein lies the futility. You'll have to decide for yourselves, of course, for who am I but a person living a fairly comfortable and secure life in the US? I know not first hand of having to fight for a home, making me a poor judge of such things. Yes, I'll need to ponder this awhile.

title: some flaws
review:
here are some of the flaws that I saw. 1)Unlike Schindler's List, it didn't draw in the viewer. The acting was excellent but Avner remained emotionally unattached to the AUDIENCE. He was not someone that we (or I) could identify with. 2)the subplots weren't developed. Who were the different people? Why were the Israelis chasing them (besides being terrorists)? The role of some of the terrorists was unclear. 3)In conjuction to #2, there were too many (yes, I know that it was a global net work)who just were mentioned or appeared and just as quickly disappeared without much explanation...including the Israelis 4)The safe house scene was confusing 5)Was anyone also confused about the roles of Papa and his son? (yes, they were selling info, but why and why did Papa remain aloof from son? The garden scene with Avner: what was that about? 6)Avner's mom/ima? Why was she even IN the film? 7)it was about 45 minutes too long, it dragged in parts.

All that to say, a little on the boring side. The real event affected me profoundly.

title: Good Action/Suspense, Intriguing Story, Unsatisfying Finish
review: Munich is a great action/suspense movie, which unlike many films of its genre also has a very intriguing storyline and conflict. The problem was the movie's resolution. Munich does indeed ask very tough (and good) ethical questions, but provides answers that are WAY too easy. In case anyone is wondering, the story is not actually about the 1972 Olympic Incident-thats just the backdrop. Rather, the movie is about revenge in general, and whether violence justifies more violence. Without providing any specific plot details, my main problem with the "easy" answers is that Spielberg presents a whole complicated world with many shades of gray, then takes a black and white stance supporting one side at the end. Note: NOT for the faint of heart (there are some VERY gruesome death images).

title: Munich was Spielberg at his medium to good-great
review:
"Munich" was a good movie. I liked it. It showed a lot of mindfulness. It was good and I liked it. It shows that violence solves very little, but that people still have a strong impulse toward "an eye for an eye," and that given particular circumstances, it's all very complicated and hard to figure out.

The movie itself was great, in that it left you with the feeling that "you were on your own," in regard to resolving the pain, conflict, and political problems inherent in the struggle against terrorism / resolution of the Mideast conflict.

As far as the Mideast conflict goes, the state of Israel has a right to exist and so does a Palestinian state have the right to exist.

The following is just an observation -- not a judgment call -- but I couldn't even picture Israelis trespassing onto an Olympic compound and murdering fellow human beings (( Maybe if they were very far right-wingers ?? )) Then again, they have a thriving country out there. If they were living the way some of the Palestinians have to live, maybe they'd find killing easy and not have to go through some of the soul-searching Avner has to go through.

But I digress from the movie. Anyway, I guess there are just three races of people -- kind and unassuming . . . hateful and murderous . . . and Spielberg imitators. If only we had his money . . . and Tom Cruise's . . . and Tom Jones'.
